instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message: I have been reading and not finding a good answer. Is pin 8 of <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> an output to the smc or in input from it?

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message:
Pin 8 is 3.3V output for AD/DA converters from SMC.
That is a reference voltage and must be very stable.
If that voltage is not present, usually board can only start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message: thank you! what types of things would cause low voltage on that line, is that most often a failing smc?

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message: Also corroded filtering capacitors on that line....

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> could be bad itself, or even SMC.
But you must start checking the filter caps.
Recently had problems with one Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
As it only started in SMC bypass, I waste lot of time checking all sensors output level; all found to be good.
Finally, I remebered that I forgot to check <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> presence; such a simply thing.
Once I changed <CAPACITOR>C5125</CAPACITOR> (found to be shorted), board started properly...

threads.title: <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> question
threads.message: Thanks for taking your valuable time to answer this. It helps me immensely trying to sort stuff out in my head :-)
